revision.text:
{{other people|Sean Hayes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Sean Hayes | image = Sean Hayes (portrait).jpg | caption = Hayes in 2010 | birth_name = Sean Patrick Hayes | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1970|6|26}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, singer, comedian, producer | years_active = 1996–present | website = | spouse = {{marriage|Scott Icenogle|2014}} }} '''Sean Patrick Hayes''' (born June 26, 1970) is an American actor, singer, comedian, and producer. He is best known for his role as [[Jack McFarland]] on the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Will & Grace]]'', for which he won an [[Emmy Award]], four [[SAG Award]]s, and one American Comedy Award, and earned six [[Golden Globe]] nominations.Stated in interview on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]''.{{Verify-inline|date=February 2015|comment=Needs episode and time mark.}}{{Verify-inline|date=February 2015|comment=Needs episode and time mark.}} He also runs a television production company called Hazy Mills Productions, which produces shows such as ''[[Grimm (TV series)|Grimm]]'', ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]'', ''[[The Soul Man]]'', and ''[[Hollywood Game Night]]''. He is known for his film work in movies such as ''[[Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss]]'', ''[[Cats & Dogs]]'', ''[[Pieces of April]]'', ''[[The Cat in the Hat (film)|The Cat in the Hat]]'', ''[[Win a Date with Tad Hamilton!]]'', ''[[The Bucket List]]'', and ''[[The Three Stooges (2012 film)|The Three Stooges]]''. He is also known for his work on Broadway such as ''[[An Act of God]]'' and ''[[Promises, Promises (musical)|Promises, Promises]]'', where he played Chuck Baxter and received a nomination for [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Musical]]. ==Early life== Hayes was born in Chicago, the youngest child of Mary Hayes (1939-2018),http://www.dailyherald.com/news/20180126/food-bank-leader---mother-of-sean-hayes---recalled-for-her-dedication the director of a non-profit [[food bank]], and Ronald Hayes, a [[lithographer]].{{cite web | title=Sean Hayes Biography | url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/68/Sean-Hayes.html | work=filmreference | year=2008 | accessdate=June 11, 2010}} He is of [[Irish people|Irish]] descent and was raised as a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] in the [[Chicago suburbs|Chicago suburb]] of [[Glen Ellyn, Illinois]]. His father left when Hayes was five years old, and he and his siblings were raised by their mother. He has not spoken to his father in many years.{{cite news | first=William | last=Keck | title=It's Not Easy Being Jack | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2000/dec/24/entertainment/ca-4036 | work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] | date=December 24, 2000 | archiveurl=http://www.angelfire.com/il3/rachelzworld/latimes.html | archivedate = December 27, 2000 | accessdate=February 4, 2015 }} After graduating from [[Glenbard West High School]],{{cite news | url = http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20130122/news/701229961/ | title = Sean Hayes, suburban pal team up for TV success | date = 2013-01-22 | first1 = Jamie | last1 = Sotonoff | first2 = Dann | last2 = Gire | work = [[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]] | location = [[Arlington Heights, Illinois]] | accessdate = 2015-02-05 }} Hayes attended [[Illinois State University]], where he studied [[piano]] performance. He left "two or three classes short" of graduation when he became [[music director]] at the Pheasant Run Theater in [[St. Charles, Illinois]]. Hayes worked as a [[classical music|classical]] [[pianist]].{{cite book|last=Marshall|first=Corinne|title=The Q Guide to Will and Grace: Stuff You Didn't Even Know You Wanted to Know... About Will, Grace, Jack, Karen, and Lots of Guest Stars|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HikbAQAAIAAJ|year=2008|publisher=Alyson Publications|isbn=978-1-59350-083-2|page=79|quote=In the early days of his career, he supported himself as a classical pianist.}} He practiced improv at [[The Second City]] in Chicago.{{cite news | first=Ari |last=Karpel | title=Sean Hayes: I Am Who I Am | url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/people/2010/03/08/sean-hayes-i-am-who-i-am | work=[[The Advocate]] | date=April 2010 | accessdate=February 22, 2014}} He also composed original music for a production of ''[[Antigone (Sophocles)|Antigone]]'' at the [[Steppenwolf Theatre Company]] in Chicago.{{cite book|last=Magazine|first=People|title=People: Almanac 2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RMFlLXWVZr8C|year=2002|publisher=Cader Books|isbn=978-1-929049-96-7|page=380|quote=Composed original music for a Steppenwolf production of Antigone.}} He moved to [[Los Angeles]] in 1995, where he found work as a [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]] and an actor on stage and {{citation needed|date=February 2015}} on television, including a [[television commercial|commercial]] for [[Doritos]] which aired during [[Super Bowl XXXII]] in 1998. ==Career== As a teenager, Hayes was an extra in the film ''[[Lucas (film)|Lucas]]'' (1986), which was filmed at [[Glenbard West High School|his high school]]. He made his professional debut in the [[independent film]] ''[[Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss]]'' (1998), which brought him wide attention. The same year, he was cast as [[Jack McFarland]], a flamboyantly [[gay]] and frequently unemployed actor, in the [[NBC]] comedy series ''[[Will & Grace]]''. The show became a long-running hit and Hayes' performance earned him seven consecutive [[Emmy Award]] nominations as [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series]]. He won the award for his first nomination.{{Verify-inline|date=February 2015|comment=Needs episode and time mark.}} He was also nominated for six [[Golden Globe Award]]s for his performance. Hayes also made film appearances in ''[[Cats & Dogs]]'' (2001), as [[Jerry Lewis]] in ''[[Martin and Lewis (film)|Martin and Lewis]]'' (2002), Wayne in ''[[Pieces of April]]'' (2003), ''[[The Cat in the Hat (film)|The Cat in the Hat]]'' (2003), and ''[[Win a Date With Tad Hamilton!]]'' (2004). He was also the voice of Brain in the 2008 film ''[[Igor (film)|Igor]]'', and has guest starred in television shows such as ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'' and ''[[30 Rock]]''. In 2005, he was [[executive producer]] for [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo]]'s ''[[Situation: Comedy]]'', a [[reality television]] series about sitcoms. He also executive produced ''[[The Sperm Donor]]'' and ''Stephen's Life'', the two winning scripts that were chosen by NBC. He guest-starred in 2006 in the [[Adult Swim]] [[Cameo appearance|cameo]]-filled show ''[[Tom Goes to the Mayor]]''.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} Hayes appeared as Thomas in the film ''[[The Bucket List]]'' (2007). On July 5, 2008, he made his New York stage debut as Mr. Applegate / Devil in [[New York City Center]]'s ''[[Encores!]]'' production of ''[[Damn Yankees]]''.{{cite news | first=Celia | last=McGee | title=Selling His Soul for the Part | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/06/theater/06mcge.html?8dpc=&_r=3&adxnnl=1&oref=slogin&adxnnlx=1218596404-GpRhqaBreKmsEu7JVLJb1Q | work=The New York Times | date=July 6, 2008 | accessdate=June 11, 2010}} He also appeared as Mr. Hank Hummerfloob and the voice of "The Fish" in ''[[The Cat in the Hat (film)|The Cat in the Hat]]''. In a 2008 ''[[New York Times]]'' interview, Hayes talked about a television project, ''BiCoastal'', about "a guy with a wife and kids in California and a boyfriend in New York" for [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]].{{cite news | url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/new-deal-cbs-swinger-118540 | title = New deal for CBS swinger | work = The Hollywood Reporter | last = Andreeva | first = Nellie | agency = Associated Press | date = September 4, 2008 | accessdate = 2015-02-05 }} He made his Broadway debut in the April 2010 Broadway revival of the musical ''[[Promises, Promises (musical)|Promises, Promises]]''. He received a nomination for the [[Drama League Award]] for Distinguished Performance, and was nominated for a [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Musical]]. Hayes was host of the [[64th Tony Awards|64th Annual Tony Awards]] on June 13, 2010 on CBS.{{cite news | first=Gina |last=DiNunno | url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Sean-Hayes-Tonys-1018881.aspx | title=Sean Hayes to Host the Tonys | work=TVGuide | date=May 24, 2010 | accessdate=June 11, 2010}} In 2010, he reprised the role of Mr. Tinkles, the evil white Persian cat, in ''[[Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore]]''. On November 15, 2010, he appeared in a satirical PSA for the repeal of [[Don't Ask, Don't Tell]] on ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]''. He played [[Larry Fine]] in the film ''[[The Three Stooges (2012 film)|The Three Stooges]]'' (2012).{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantadowntown.com/_files/docs/three_stooges.pdf|title=Filming at 5 Points Sports Building – Downtown Atlanta/Fairlie Poplar District|publisher=atlantadowntown.com|date=April 28, 2011|accessdate=June 27, 2011}} Aware that his role in ''Will & Grace'' "wouldn't go on forever", Hayes teamed up with his friend Todd Milliner, whom he met at Illinois State University, to create the television production company Hazy Mills Productions in 2004.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zS4zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fAgGAAAAIBAJ&pg=5309,6966636&dq=hazy+mills+productions&hl=en|title=Oh curses, it's hard: 'Will & Grace' stars try to beat odds|last=Byrne|first=Bridget|date=July 21, 2006|agency=Associated Press|publisher=The Free Lance – Star |archiveurl=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Jul/21/en/FP607210324.html |archivedate = July 21, 2006 | accessdate=August 18, 2013}}{{cite web | author=Staff writers | title=Development Update: Eight Days a Week (The CW, New!) | url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=7311 | work=The Futon Critic | date=March 1, 2010 | accessdate=June 11, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://hazymills.com/Hazy_Mills_Productions/The_Company.html |title=The Company |work=Hazy Mills Productions |accessdate=August 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130803040104/http://www.hazymills.com/Hazy_Mills_Productions/The_Company.html |archivedate=August 3, 2013 }}{{cite web|last=Rose|first=Lacey|title=When Did Sean Hayes and Todd Milliner Take Over TV?|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/did-sean-hayes-todd-milliner-630155|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=September 19, 2013}} The company has produced multiple American television series, including ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]'', ''[[Grimm (TV series)|Grimm]]'', ''[[The Soul Man]]'', ''[[Hollywood Game Night]]'' and ''[[Sean Saves the World]]''. Hayes is co-executive producer of the [[TV Land]] original comedy series ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]'', which premiered in June 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.inbaseline.com/company.aspx?company_id=4619318|title=Page not found|website=inbaseline.com|accessdate=July 13, 2017}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He is also a co-executive producer of the [[NBC]] series ''[[Grimm (TV series)|Grimm]]'',{{Cite news|url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/01/breaking-nbc-orders-brothers-grimm-themed-pilot/|title=NBC Orders Brothers Grimm-Themed Drama From Buffy Scribe|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|work=[[TVLine]]|date=January 28, 2011|accessdate=October 15, 2011}} as well as creator and executive producer on another NBC series, ''[[Hollywood Game Night]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/12/18/nbc-announces-bold-new-game-show-hollywood-game-night/162335/|title=NBC Announces Bold New Game Show 'Hollywood Game Night'|last=Kondology|first=Amanda|work=[[TV by the Numbers]]|publisher=Zap2it|date=December 18, 2012|accessdate=June 11, 2013}} Hayes and his husband, Scott Icenogle, produce lip-sync videos under their YouTube channel, The Kitchen Sync.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSCO7m_SlhyVlmeEdnBZiNQ|title=The Kitchen Sync|website=YouTube|accessdate=July 13, 2017}} They lip-synced to songs such as ''[[Trouble (Iggy Azalea song)|Trouble]]'' & ''[[Burnitup!]]'' He was the host of ''An All Star Tribute to James Burrows''. Hayes starred in the Broadway play ''[[An Act of God]]'', which ran from June 6, 2016 to September 4, 2016. In 2017, Hayes played the role of Steven, the [[devil]] emoji in ''[[The Emoji Movie]]''. ==Personal life== Hayes refused to discuss his [[sexual orientation]] for many years, saying he believed that audiences would therefore be more open-minded about his characters.{{cite interview | subject=Sean Hayes | interviewer=[[Terry Gross]] | title=Will And Grace' Star Sean Hayes Steps To Broadway | url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126219932 | type=Interview: audio/transcript | work=Fresh Air | publisher=NPR / WHYY | date=April 29, 2010 | accessdate=June 11, 2010}} In a 2010 interview with ''[[The Advocate]]'', he appeared to imply that he is [[Homosexuality|gay]], stating: "Really? You're gonna shoot the gay guy down? I never have had a problem saying who I am. I am who I am." He also indicated that he was in a relationship. He states that he feels like he has "contributed monumentally to the success of the gay movement in America, and if anyone wants to argue that, I'm open to it". He received an [[honorary degree|honorary]] [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] from [[Illinois State University]] in February 2013.{{cite web|last=Sobota |first=Lenore |url=http://www.pantagraph.com/news/local/education/actor-sean-hayes-former-fairleigh-dickinson-president-receive-honorary-degrees/article_dd585e18-7c84-11e2-98b8-001a4bcf887a.html |title=Actor Sean Hayes, former Fairleigh Dickinson president receive honorary degrees |publisher=Pantagraph.com |date=2013-02-21 |accessdate=2014-02-06}} In November 2014 Hayes announced that he had married his partner of eight years, Scott Icenogle.{{cite web | first=Cavan |last=Sieczkowski | title=Sean Hayes Marries Longtime Partner Scott Icenogle | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/11/20/sean-hayes-marries_n_6192854.html | work=[[The Huffington Post]] | date=November 2014 | accessdate=November 20, 2014}} In October 2017, while appearing on an episode of ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', Hayes revealed that he had been hospitalized with a rare condition in which his small intestine burst. The intestine was successfully repaired.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sean-hayes-was-hospitalized-his-small-intestine-burst-1051703|title=Sean Hayes Was Hospitalized After His Small Intestine Burst|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- | 1996 || ''[[A&P (short story)|A&P]]'' || Sammy || |- | 1998 || ''[[Billy's Hollywood Screen Kiss]]'' || Billy Collier{{cite book|last1=Beltran|first1=Mary C.|last2=Fojas|first2=Camilla|title=Mixed Race Hollywood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0nsTCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA118|date=1 August 2008|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0-8147-9989-5|page=118}} || |- | 2000 || ''[[Buzz Lightyear of Star Command: The Adventure Begins]]'' || Brain Pod #13 || Voice |- | 2001 || ''[[Cats & Dogs]]'' || Mr. Tinkles{{cite book|last1=Rosen|first1=Ronald|last2=Hornberger|first2=Francine|title=So You Think You Know about Cats?: An All-in-one Guide for Felines and Their Humans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qYYjdA4dYkAC&pg=PA35|year=2006|publisher=Citadel|isbn=978-0-8065-2749-9|page=35}} || Voice |- | 2003 || ''[[Pieces of April]]'' || Wayne || |- | 2003 || ''[[The Cat in the Hat (film)|The Cat in the Hat]]'' || Mr. Hank Humberfloob/ Voice of the Fish || |- | 2004 || ''[[Win a Date with Tad Hamilton!]]'' || Richard Levy || |- | 2005 || ''Roberto the Insect Architect'' || Narrator || |- | 2007 || ''[[The Bucket List]]'' || Matthew || |- | 2008 || ''Man Stroke Woman'' || Various || |- | 2008 || ''[[Soul Men (film)|Soul Men]]'' || Danny Epstein || |- | 2008 || ''[[Igor (film)|Igor]]'' || Brain || Voice |- | 2010 || ''[[Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore]]'' || Mr. Tinkles || Voice |- | 2012 || ''[[The Three Stooges (2012 film)|The Three Stooges]]'' || [[Larry Fine]] || |- | 2012 || ''[[Hit and Run (2012 film)|Hit and Run]]'' || Sandy Osterman || |- | 2013 || ''[[Monsters University]]'' || Terri Perry || Voice |- | 2014 || ''[[How Murray Saved Christmas]]'' || Edison Elf || Voice |- | 2017 || ''[[The Emoji Movie]]'' || Steven || Voice |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
